metadata.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji

facts.text: Respondent Rao Manohar Singhji is the owner of the Jagir of Bedla situate in the former State of Mewar.
Former State of Mewar was integrated in April 1948 to form the former United State of Rajasthan.

In April and May 1949, the former United State of Rajasthan was amalgamated with former States of Bikaner, Jaipur, Jaisalmer, Jodhpur and former Union of Matsya to form the present United State of Rajasthan.
Three Ordinances issued: No. XXVII of 1948, Nos. X and XV of 1949, by former State of Rajasthan in connection with State Jagirs.
Management of Jagirs including Jagir of Bedla assumed by former State of Rajasthan under powers in these Ordinances.
After final formation of State of Rajasthan in May 1949, Ordinances remained in force in part of present area, resulting in jagirs managed by State in that area while untouched in rest.
Respondent filed petition under Article 226 on 4th January 1951 contending Ordinances ultra vires Constitution, void under Article 13(1) read with Articles 14 and 31.
Respondent challenged Ordinances as infringing Articles 14, 19 and 31; prejudicially affecting only Jagirdars of former State of Rajasthan formed in 1948, while others not affected.

State replied that Jagir was State grant held at pleasure of Ruler, reverted on death, regranted after recognition; rights not heritable/transferable, no compensation under Article 31(2); Ordinances transfer management only, not deprive property.
State denied discrimination under Article 14.

High Court held provisions of Ordinances Nos. X and XV of 1949 not void under Article 31(2) or 19(1)(f); but section 8-A introduced in Ordinance XXVII of 1948 by Ordinance X of 1949 and amended by Ordinance XV of 1949 void under Article 13(1) read with Article 14.
High Court issued writ restraining State from collecting rents from tenants of lands comprising Jagir of Bedla.
Appeal filed on certificate under Article 132(1) by High Court of Rajasthan.
Ordinance No. I of 1948 (United State of Rajasthan Administration Ordinance, 1948) made on April 28, 1948.
Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948 (United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars Abolition of Powers Ordinance, 1948) made on July 26, 1948, abolishing judicial/executive powers of Jagirdars.
Section 8-A introduced by Ordinance X of 1949: revenue heretofore collected by Jagirdars shall henceforth be collected by Government, which after deducting expenses pays to Jagirdar.
Section 8-A amended by Ordinance XV of 1949 adding 'Including taxes, cesses and other revenue from forests'.
Upon formation of Rajasthan in 1949, Jagirdars in only part (former Rajasthan) could not collect rents, while in other areas (Jaipur etc.) no such disability.
Constitution came into force January 26, 1950; Article 13 declares inconsistent laws void.
Since High Court judgment, State passed Acts abolishing Jagirs throughout State, but question affects respondent's right to collect rents for short period.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Ordinances constitute infringement of Articles 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution.

Whether section 8-A inserted in Ordinance XXVII of 1948 by Ordinance X of 1949 and amended by Ordinance XV of 1949 is void under Article 14 due to discrimination against Jagirdars of former State of Rajasthan.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decision of High Court that impugned section 8-A as amended hit by Article 14 is erroneous.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; reasonable classification; geographical consideration; precedents like Frank J. Bowman v. Edward A. Lewis

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrimination based on geographical consideration justifiable as Jagirs in particular area governed by different laws of tenure.
High Court cases Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar and Raja Hari Singh v. Rajasthan did not adhere to view in judgment under appeal.

respondent_arguments.text: Ordinances ultra vires, void under Article 13(1) read with Articles 14 and 31; infringe Articles 14, 19, 31.
Denial of equality: only Jagirdars of former State of Rajasthan prejudicially affected, not others.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held section 8-A void under Article 14; discrimination not based on reasonable classification, manifestly unreasonable and arbitrary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No substantial distinction shown between Jagirdars of affected area and others; no evidence of different laws of tenure or conditions justifying differentiation.

court_reasoning.text: Discrimination arose post-integration by reason of prior disability in former Rajasthan area, not inherent in Ordinances; hit by Article 14 post-Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proper classification must bear reasonable relation to things classified.

court_reasoning.text: No occasion after new State formation to take away powers from Jagirdars in disfavoured area while leaving intact in rest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pre-Constitution discrimination not objectionable until Article 13 applied.

court_reasoning.text: Frank J. Bowman inapplicable as no continuation of old laws in one portion; no peculiarity in former Rajasthan Jagirs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination based on municipal considerations alone not applicable here.

court_reasoning.text: Ramjilal distinguishable; State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh allows geographical classification for abducted persons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reasonable basis here unlike those cases.

court_reasoning.text: Rajasthan High Court cases distinguished on facts: reasonable basis existed there (District Boards, ameliorative legislation).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bench adhered to view in appealed judgment.

holdings.text: Section 8-A of Ordinance XXVII of 1948 as amended is void under Article 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Frank J. Bowman v. Edward A. Lewis
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied on by State for geographical/municipal discrimination permissible; court held inapplicable as no continuation of different laws.
Pending proceedings concluded under prior law reasonable; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Geographical classification valid for abducted persons Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasonable basis for continuing Jaipur District Boards post-integration.
Mewar tenancy/revenue laws ameliorative, no discrimination without similar laws elsewhere.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Ordinances challenged as violating equality (14), property rights (19,31); Article 13 voids inconsistent pre-Constitution laws.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948 (United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars Abolition of Powers Ordinance)
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished powers of Jagirdars; section 8-A directed revenue collection by Government.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Ordinance No. X of 1949 (United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars Abolition of Powers Amendment Ordinance)
Rajasthan Ordinance No. XV of 1949 (United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars Abolition of Powers 2nd Amendment Ordinance)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended section 8-A to include taxes, cesses, forest revenue.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Ordinance No. I of 1948 (United State of Rajasthan Administration Ordinance)

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's judgment declaring section 8-A void under Article 14, prohibiting State from collecting rents from tenants of Bedla Jagir; appeal by State dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ upheld restraining State from collecting rents.

key_quotes.text: Judged by this criterion it seems to us that the discrimination is based on no classification at all and is manifestly unreasonable and arbitrary.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 8-A of the impugned Ordinance as amended is a clear contravention of the respondents right under article 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There was no reason for taking away from the Jagirdars by section 8-A the power to collect rents to which they were entitled.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's view on lack of distinction, endorsed by Supreme Court.
